page.title: 03Buildings of Interest.
page.content: Like so many old villages,Brereton had its own{water-mill,}but because it had to be built where there was a constant supply of water,it stands about a mile from the centre of the village,in the valley of the{River Croco. } The present mill was built in about 1800 on the site of previous mills thought to go back to the original Domesday period.The mill is in part now used for living accomodation,but the workings and wheel are still in existence awaiting a new lease of life {The church ofSt.Oswald}stands in peaceful surroundings near the Hall. The earliest date that can be identified with this beautiful church is around 1200 AD. Perpendicular in style,the fabric was rebuilt during the 15th Century.Now built of red sandstone,there are clues that the original construction was of timber.
